column2: 23 Nov 2019 10:29:10 -0500	Ex-CIA Officer Sentenced to 19 Years in Chinese Espionage Conspiracy	https://news.yahoo.com/ex-cia-officer-sentenced-19-152355446.html	"ALEXANDRIA
column3: Va. -- A former CIA officer was sentenced Friday to 19 years inprison for conspiring to deliver classified information to China in a casethat touched on the mysterious unraveling of the agency's informant network inChina but did little to solve it.The former officer
column6: pleaded guilty in May to conspiring with Chinese intelligence agents startingin 2010
column7: after he left the agency. Prosecutors detailed a long financial papertrail that they said showed that Lee received more than $840
column10: worked for the CIA from 1994 to 2007
column12: he formed a tobacco company in Hong Kong with anassociate who had ties to the Chinese intelligence community. Lee then beganmeeting with agents from China's Ministry of State Security
column13: who assigned himtasks he admitted to taking on and offered to ""take care of him forlife.""While working in Hong Kong in 2010
column14: Lee reapplied for employment withthe CIA but misled U.S. officials repeatedly in interviews about his dealingswith Chinese intelligence officers and the source of his income.Around thetime Lee began speaking to Chinese agents
column15: the CIA was rocked by majorsetbacks in China as its once-robust espionage network there began to fallapart. Between 2010 and 2012
column16: dozens of CIA informants in China disappeared
column18: embroiling the agency in an internal debate about howChinese intelligence officers had identified the informants. Many within theagency came to believe that a mole had exposed U.S. informants
column19: and Lee becamea main suspect.But FBI agents who investigated whether he was the culpritpassed on an opportunity to arrest him in the United States in 2013
column20: allowinghim to travel back to Hong Kong even after finding classified information inhis luggage. FBI agents had also covertly entered a hotel room Lee occupied in2012
column21: finding handwritten notes detailing the names and numbers of at leasteight CIA sources that he had handled in his capacity as a case officer.Theinvestigators apparently decided that by continuing to quietly monitor Lee
column22: they might glean more clues about the disappearing CIA informants in China.But even after his arrest in 2018 on the same charge the CIA was prepared tobring in 2013
column23: they were unable to determine whether Lee was involved in thedisclosures to Chinese intelligence operatives.Because of Lee's pleaagreement
column24: in which he admitted to one count of possessing informationclassified as secret -- a lower level than top secret -- prosecutors asked fora relatively lighter sentence of roughly 22 to 27 years
column25: rather than life inprison.But prosecutors argued that even if Lee never turned over informationto Chinese intelligence officers
column26: the fact that he shared his knowledge ofU.S. intelligence work with Chinese agents alone could have a chilling effecton the CIA's source-building efforts.""It makes it difficult to recruit peoplein the future if they know the CIA isn't protecting their people
column28: a federal prosecutor in Northern Virginia
column29: where Lee was charged.""These are people who put their names and lives in his hands.""The sentence forLee is the latest in a string of recent cases in which U.S. intelligenceworkers have been handed lengthy prison terms for espionage connected toChina. In announcing Lee's sentence
column30: Judge T.S. Ellis III said that a heftysentence was necessary to deter others from jeopardizing U.S. intelligence.InMay
column32: Kevin Patrick Mallory was sentenced to 20 yearsin prison for selling classified documents to a Chinese intelligence officerfor $25
column34: who presided over that case as well
column35: decided that a lifesentence for Mallory was excessively harsh even though prosecutors showed hesuccessfully transmitted secret information.In September
column37: a former Defense Intelligence Agency officer
column38: received 10 years in prison forattempting to pass along defense secrets.Lee's lawyers argued that the largelycircumstantial case against him was considerably weaker than others in whichdefendants were charged with espionage
column39: and that speculating that theunexplained payments he received were compensation for information that harmedCIA operations was ""a bridge too far.""Although Lee pleaded guilty toconspiring with Chinese agents
column40: lawyers on both sides conceded that there wasno direct evidence that Lee ever provided any of the classified information inhis possession to the Chinese government. The CIA has not shown that thesources listed in Lee's notes faced retribution or harm
column41: Lee's lawyerssaid.""What the government is describing is their worst possible nightmare
column43: one of Lee's lawyers.In announcing the sentence
column44: Ellissaid he was not convinced that Lee's interactions with Chinese intelligenceofficers were benign
column45: and that it is common in espionage cases to never fullyuncover the extent of illicit dealings.While he acknowledged that Lee
column46: anaturalized citizen born in Hong Kong
column47: had done a great deal with his life asan American -- four years in the Army
column48: a 13-year career with the CIA -- Ellisappeared unmoved.""That gets erased
column50: ""when you betray yourcountry.""This article originally appeared in The New York Times.(C) 2019 TheNew York Times Company  "	['https://news.yahoo.com/ex-cia-officer-sentenced-19-152355446.html'
